Consumer complaint narrative:
American express ( along with other credit card companies ) have a policy of updating merchants who post recurring transactions with new consumer credit card numbers as they change ... so that the merchant and consumers do not experience the inconvenience of having to update accounts each time a credit card changes. I get this ... but there is a major downside that I am surprised no one has challenged yet. 

The below may be generalized statements ... but they help paint a picture : The issuers generally do not allow the consumer to opt-in to this program The issuers do not allow the consumer to know who has been provided access to the new credit card number ( no notification ) The issuers make it difficult for consumers to manage who can hit their credit card with recurring transactions. ( you have to call and tell the issuers who to block - assuming you know which merchant has the new information ) There is a huge potential for fraud with this process, and it seems in this day and age, the idea that someone can provide my personal updated credit card information to vendors I want to stop doing business with seems outrageous. At a minimum, i should be allowed to opt in or out.

Consumer complaint narrative: I want to make CFPB aware of another issue with Navient that has troubled me - they make it extremely difficult to find out how your payment is allocated - interest and principle - declining balance. Every other lender I know shows your prior statement balance, your payments made, how much went to interest and to principle, and then ending balance. In this way you can see if, for example, your minimum payment of {$750.00} on your student loan payment, only pays down your principle by {$79.00} dollars with the rest going to interest. My loans are consolidated with them, and I have previously raised this issue with customer service, and they had no answer other than the website was being redesigned ( this was over a year ago ). I have figured out how to do this manually, but the average student loan payer will not go to the trouble. You have to go to their " archived '' old site, then to your emails ( all my communication is electronic ), then gather your monthly statements, then write down your prior balance, payments, interest and principle, and manually review the declining balance. This is how I figured out that on many months only a tiny % of my large payment was going to principle. This to me is a very deceitful way to do business - by making it so difficult to understand the declining balance, and thus how much you are actually paying off without manually tracking it, they are encouraging everyone to remain in huge debt as long as possible. They should be made to put this on the main page of the borrowers ' loan balances - they already have the payment amounts, it would take very little programming to add this. It seems as if Navient is purposely omitting this information to keep borrowers on the hook for as long as possible since if people knew they only had a small amount going to principle they would be motivated to pay their loans off sooner.
